docs.lead_paragraph: California, Illinois and Pennsylvania announced Thursday that they had joined at least 11 other states in taking emergency action to help low-income Medicare beneficiaries struggling to fill prescriptions under Medicare's new drug program. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, a Republican, said ''the state will be the payer of last resort'' for nearly one million low-income people entitled to both Medicare and Medicaid.

headline.main: 3 More States To Intervene In Drug Plan

docs.snippet: California, Illinois and Pennsylvania joined at least 11 other states to help low-income Medicare beneficiaries struggling under Medicare's new drug program.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 U.S. Sees an Opportunity In Split Among Insurgents American and Iraqi officials believe the recent violent clashes between Iraqi insurgents and Al Qaeda present them with one of the biggest opportunities since the insurgency began, and they have begun talking with local insurgents, hoping to enlist them to cooperate with them against the terrorist group. A1 Swiss Paper Leak Investigated Switzerland has begun criminal investigations to track down the source of a leak to the Zurich-based newspaper SonntagsBlick of what it reported was a secret document referring to clandestine C.I.A. prisons in Eastern Europe. A11 Iran and Europe at Odds After Iran moved to break the internationally monitored seals on its nuclear facilities, a contest of wills between Iran and its adversaries unfolded, with the Europeans threatening to refer Iran to the United Nations Security Council for possible punitive actions and Iran issuing defiant new warnings. A6 Norway Pounds at Glass Ceiling Norway's leftist government put into effect one of the more radical attempts to achieve sexual equality: requiring that 40 percent of the board members of the nation's large, publicly traded private companies be women. A3 Turkish Flu Response Criticized International experts said that while Turkish officials were taking appropriate measures, their initial slow response to outbreaks of avian influenza have created a health crisis that may be difficult to remedy. A8 Global Warming as a Frog Killer Scientists studying a fast-dwindling genus of colorful harlequin frogs on misty mountainsides in Central and South America report that global warming is combining with a spreading fungus to kill off many species. But experts on amphibian disease and ecology are divided over the finding, which is being published today in the journal Nature. A12 Israel Ends Talks With Preacher Israel said it was breaking off negotiations on a tourism project with the evangelical leader Pat Robertson, left, in response to his remarks suggesting that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's stroke was divine retribution. A16 Chinese Respond to Toxic Spills Two recent chemical spills have forced Chinese officials in two different regions to take emergency precautions to protect water supplies for millions of people in the latest examples of the environmental and public health threats posed by the nation's industrial pollution. A16 Scientist's House Raided Dr. Hwang Woo Suk, the disgraced stem cell scientist, apologized for falsifying data in his research. Prosecutors also raided his home and labs to investigate work that had propelled South Korea to the top of global stem cell research before it was found to be fraudulent. A15 NATIONAL A18-29 Democrats Prod Nominee For Specifics at Hearing Democrats tried with increasing frustration to elicit more specific views from Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. about abortion and other topics and sought to build a case against his nomination to the Supreme Court by raising questions about his character and consistency. A1 A Tough Fight for DeLay Representative Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas, finds himself in the toughest re-election campaign of his 11-term House career, in part because of the Congressional redistricting scheme he spearheaded. A1 New Orleans Plan Draws Fire Residents of the city's most devastated neighborhoods responded with anger after the city's rebuilding commission unveiled its most contentious proposal: giving neighborhoods in low-lying parts of the city from four months to a year to prove they should not be bulldozed. A18 Court Access for Condemned An argument before the Supreme Court in a 20-year-old murder case suggested that the court might be willing to open the door a bit wider to death row inmates seeking access to federal court to present plausible but belated claims of innocence. A28 Bishop Says He Was Abused Saying he had been sexually abused as a teenage seminarian, a Roman Catholic Bishop became the highest-ranking member of the church to endorse legislation in various states that would loosen the statute of limitations on lawsuits relating to sexual abuse by clergy members. A20 Author Made Up Details of Life James Frey, the author of ''A Million Little Pieces,'' which has been the best-selling book in the country since Oprah Winfrey selected it last fall for her television book club, acknowledged that he had made up details of his life on ''Larry King Live'' on CNN. But he maintained that what he believes is the essence of the book is true. Ms. Winfrey, in a telephone call to Mr. King's program, said she believed the book's underlying message was true, adding that she would continue to recommend it. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 For Many Asians, America Means Pounds and Peril Asians, especially those from Far Eastern nations like China, Korea and Japan, are acutely susceptible to Type 2 diabetes, the most common form of the disease, a factor that is compounded by a sudden collision with and adaptation to the American diet. A1 New York Faces Voting Suit The Justice Department has threatened to sue New York State over its failure to modernize its voting system, saying the city ''is further behind'' every other state in the nation in complying with new guidelines stemming from the 2000 presidential election. B1 Golisano Considers Running Tom Golisano plans to announce by the end of January if he will run for governor of New York this year, but Republican leaders say they believe he will indeed seek their party's nomination. B1 Inquiry Into Girl's Death A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl was found beaten to death inside her home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where evidence suggested she had been kept apart from her five siblings and kept bound to a chair in her room, a law enforcement official said. B1 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-8 HOUSE & HOME F1-12 THURSDAY STYLES G1-8 ARTS E1-10 OBITUARIES B6-7 Birgit Nilsson The Swedish soprano with a voice of impeccable trueness and impregnable stamina, she was 87. A1 Sidney E. Frank The businessman who concocted spectacularly successful marketing campaigns for Jägermeister liqueur and Grey Goose vodka, he was 86. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-17 Johnson Raises Guidant Bid Johnson & Johnson reached a new agreement with Guidant, raising its bid to $23.2 billion and pre-empting a rival offer from Boston Scientific. But several people close to Boston Scientific suggested the company was planning a new offer. C1 China's Trade Surplus Grows China said its trade surplus with the rest of the world had tripled in 2005, to a record $102 billion, a figure that could reignite global trade frictions and step up pressure on the government to allow its currency to appreciate further. C1 Turnover at Morgan Stanley Morgan Stanley sustained its first high-level executive departures of the new year in a sign that the poaching that plagued the firm during its leadership struggle has flared up again. C1 Criticism of Realtors' Group The National Association of Realtors has come under fire from a broad range of critics who say the organization and its state and local affiliates have worked to smother competition. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: Judge Alito, in his own words; an incendiary threat in Iraq; drugs and racial discrimination. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E4 TV Listings E9 Crossword E4 Weather C18
docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-17    U.S. Sees an Opportunity In Split Among Insurgents  American and Iraqi officials believe the recent violent clashes between Iraqi insurgents and Al Qaeda present them with one of the biggest opportunities since the insurgency...

docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Lapiana had an ominous family history: both his parents had Type 2 diabetes, and both died of heart disease -- the most frequent cause of death in all forms of diabetes. Since his 20's, Mr. Lapiana has had hypertension, a danger signal for diabetes and for heart disease. But until he was 50, when he mentioned his unquenchable thirst -- a symptom of diabetes -- to a doctor, Mr. Lapiana had slipped under the medical radar. The doctor tested his blood sugar and found that his glucose was five times as high as the normal level.
docs.abstract: Evidence continues to mount supporting link between diabetes and heart disease; recent study published in New England Journal of Medicine holds that aggressively lowering person's blood sugar level can cut risk of heart attack and stroke almost in half; research shows that heart disease may precede symptoms of diabetes and experts agree that either condition should signal doctors to look for and treat other condition as well; treatment options discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors now have solid evidence that aggressively lowering a person's blood sugar level can cut the risk of heart attack and stroke nearly in half.

docs.lead_paragraph: The growth of national health spending slowed in 2004, mainly because insurers reined in drug costs so that spending on pharmaceuticals increased at the slowest rate in a decade, the Bush administration said Monday. Total health care spending rose 7.9 percent in 2004, to $1.9 trillion, or an average of $6,280 a person, the administration said. That represents 16 percent of the nation's economy, the highest share on record.

headline.main: Growth of National Health Spending Slows Along With Drug Sales

docs.snippet: The growth of national health spending slowed in 2004, mainly because insurers reined in spending on prescription drugs, the Bush administration said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Dick Cheney went to a hospital for four and a half hours early Monday morning after complaining of shortness of breath, but he was back at the White House in the afternoon, amid a number of unanswered questions about his condition. The White House said the 3 a.m. trip to George Washington University Hospital was necessary because of fluid retention as a side effect of a drug Mr. Cheney, 64, had taken to treat chronic foot ailments. Last week, Mr. Cheney was seen using a cane, and the White House said he had a ''pre-existing condition'' in his foot, but the problem was not described with precision.

headline.main: Cheney Makes a Morning Trip to the Hospital

docs.snippet: Vice President Dick Cheney was hospitalized after complaining of shortness of breath, but he was back at work in the afternoon.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: It is no secret that some women who take birth control pills lose interest in sex. They have been reporting this side effect to their doctors since oral contraceptives came into wide use 40 years ago. ''Little by little, my boyfriend and I started noticing that I was just never in the mood. Never,'' said Cody, a 27-year-old San Francisco woman, who asked that her last name not be used for reasons of privacy.

headline.main: When the Pill Arouses That Urge for Abstinence

docs.abstract: Boston urologist Dr Irwin Goldstein conducts study on reported link between decreased sexual desire in women and use of birth control pills; finds that sexual function does not immediately return for most women after discontinuing pills and suggests that elevated levels of sex hormone binding globulin, protein that renders free testosterone in blood inactive, is responsible; other theories about sexual desire and impact of birth control pills discussed; research is published in Journal of Sexual Medicine; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A controversial new study suggests that the birth control pill not only suppresses desire, but can also do so for months after a woman stops taking it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Low-income Medicare beneficiaries around the country were often overcharged, and some were turned away from pharmacies without getting their medications, in the first week of Medicare's new drug benefit. The problems have prompted emergency action by some states to protect their citizens. Although there are no hard numbers, concerns expressed by state officials and complaints from pharmacists suggest a widespread pattern of problems.

headline.main: STATES INTERVENE AFTER DRUG PLAN HITS EARLY SNAGS

docs.snippet: Low-income Medicare beneficiaries were often overcharged and some were turned away in the new drug benefit's first week.
